original: I'm a manager and tried to unobtrusively and politely pull the drink without causing a scene, all while explaining that it was a violation of our liquor license and I could n't allow this guest to keep the martini he had dumped into his wine glass.
In reality this `` judge'' was trying to hide his martini on the floor.
But I thought you would like to know that the manager was extremely rude to us.
As I said, we did not allow it to tarnish our evening.
If anyone should know better, you'd think it was him, except for his sense of entitlement.
I misunderstood my manager and thought that we did n't accept them at all on that night.
I interrupted her stating, `` I will go get my manager,'' and walked away.
I went and got my manager and explained to him what happened.
He took everything off their bills except drinks and appetizer.
He told her and her husband that he did n't appreciate their rude treatment of his staff, which happened every time they came in.
He told them they were no longer welcome.
I do my best to do my job to make you happy, but I will not go against the rules my manager has so you can save a buck or two.

It's freezing this time of year so I did n't want to sit near the door.

I was waiting about ten minutes in a pretty empty restaurant and noticed that no one had sat in the booth.
The waiter finally came and took my order and still no one sat in the booth.
My food came and that's when it really got weird.
In the middle of eating from my clay hot pot, the waiter came over to check how everything was.
At that point he also mentioned that the boss likes to sit at the booth I asked to sit in and that's why I could n't sit there.

At this point, she finally decides to get off the phone and gets huffy with the waitress about the `` defective teabag'' and how she needs to place her order `` right now because she's in a hurry.''
At this point I'm just sticking around to watch the show.
I had a day off and went to breakfast at one of my favorite local places, a restaurant attached to a B&B that only served breakfast and dinner.

caveman: We go to restaurant on night.
original: However... Recently we went to a familiar restaurant on a slow night.
My wife and I are retired.
The dish was not hot and barely palatable ; I believe he deliberately left it sitting before he brought it out as there were not enough other customers for the kitchen to be backed up.
I refused but also declined to tip the culprit.
I wonder, however, what we could have done differently to avoid his attitude.
When dining out, if I want a burger I will always ask the server if the place does rare and if not I will order something else.
thing and was assured they do.
It was a long day and I was tired, so I mentioned to my wife that I really did n't care if the burger was overcooked, I just wanted to eat and hit the road.
A few seconds later the server came to check on us and asked how our food was.

The server started arguing with my wife, `` I made sure the cook knew it had to be rare... the cook was going to leave it on longer but I made him take it off... etc.'' After a minute or so of listening to them argue about whether the burger was well done or rare, I just picked the burger patty up with both hands, they both stopped and looked at me, and I broke the burger patty in half with an audible snap.
About two years ago I was dining at an Asian restaurant in San Antonio with my mother and younger brother.
About two years ago I was dining at an Asian restaurant in San Antonio with my mother and younger brother.
The waitress offered to refill my mother and brother's glasses, but she never asked if I needed one.
I always had to speak up and try to get her attention for a refill.
My mum was jovially conversing with the waiter when he brought the check ; he seemed to be enjoying himself.
Still trying to keep my cool, I remained in my seat and leaned over.
Perhaps I'm a little odd, but I have a rather large territorial bubble that I DO NOT like people violating.
The food was good, the service was good, we had a fun time.
We're amicable people, and enjoy small-talk with waiters... well, my mum and sister do, I'm hard of hearing so I'm generally quiet.
We'd been seated at a booth, but I sat on a regular chair on the outside of the table -LRB- yes, my crazy bubble rules apply to even family members -RRB-.
My mum was jovially conversing with the waiter when he brought the check ; he seemed to be enjoying himself.
He was standing next to me, but I did my best to concentrate on my soda and be polite.
Dear God, he kept moving closer!
On his own accord he bid us a good day and left before I toppled out of my chair or had a psychotic episode.

original: On Saturday the 13th of March, my wife and I went into O' C's located in Avon, Indiana.

We also noticed ants crawling along the window sill.
We informed the waiter who promptly found us a new table and apologized for the ants.

Drinks were delivered and we placed our order for our dinners.

It was a good thing that they did n't prepare my meal before giving me the price!

He clearly did not notice the busy atmosphere.
He points to the space that the staff need to use to move from the restaurant to the kitchen doors.
It happened on a bank holiday and I was not at work that day.
It was also pouring with rain outside and the restaurant was very busy with only about two tables free.
The waitress just stares back at him, snatches the bill from his hand and storms off and starts shouting across the entire restaurant `` THEN I'M CHARGING YOU FULL PRICE FOR HER DESSERT!!!''
Everyone in the restaurant stares at her then at us.
A couple of months ago my husband and I were out running errands and decide to meet up with some friends at a local `` Mom & Pop'' restaurant.
These friends of ours had just ordered their lunches with their 9 month old daughter when we arrived.

My husband and I decided to just order a couple of sodas and desserts as we had a big breakfast earlier in the day and we explained to the waitress that our two orders would be on a separate ticket which seemed to confuse her.
I changed my order to some specialty chocolate cake they had without much ado.
A couple moments later our waitress arrives with the Taco Salad and melon plate my friend had ordered for herself and her daughter and just placed it in front of me without a word and breezes away.
Then she circles back with drink refills and the remaining orders and notices a melon rind on the floor that had been accidentally dropped by the 9 month old.
These friends of ours had just ordered their lunches with their 9 month old daughter when we arrived.

My husband and I decided to just order a couple of sodas and desserts as we had a big breakfast earlier in the day and we explained to the waitress that our two orders would be on a separate ticket which seemed to confuse her.
Everyone in the restaurant stares at her then at us.
I was so embarrassed by the spectacle she made us into that I just wanted to leave.
After we ordered the waitress came back and apologized saying they were out of the pecan pie I had ordered.

When it came time to pay she brings our ticket and explains that she rang us up for the pecan pie I had ordered as it was less expensive and what I wanted in the first place, but we noticed that she charged us for our friend's Taco Salad.
He was a generally quiet, well-behaved kid, even at that age, and we made sure we brought lots of quiet activities and even some Cheerios and other toddler snacks for the wait.
Our son got a little cranky so we gave him some Cheerios.
We were out of things for him to do other than sing `` Old MacDonald'' to him, which probably would n't have gone over too well with the other patrons.
Our son was now behaving the way you would expect an 18-month-old to behave after sitting in a high chair for nearly an hour watching other people eat.
We do n't blame him, but we also knew that others did n't come to this restaurant to sit beside a cranky toddler.
We waited some more, but only until we could snag our waiter, who was now quite a bit busier, since nearly an hour had passed and many more people had come in.
We got our waiter's attention and explained that we had not received our food, even though we ordered before the other party had even arrived.
We explained the situation and she called our waiter over.

Each time, he took a steak out of the box, he threw it on the scale, pointed, and yelled:  `` 10 ounces!''
There was a couple at the next table, and when their dinner was brought to the table, the man complained to the waiter that his steak was too small.
The waiter assured the man that the steak was indeed a 10 oz steak, and the man insisted that it was n't.
The manager explained to the man that 10 oz was the uncooked weight of the steak.
He put the box and the scale down on their table, and proceeded to pull raw steaks out of the box.
Each time, he took a steak out of the box, he threw it on the scale, pointed, and yelled:  `` 10 ounces!''
He then would throw that steak on the table, get another one out of the box, throw it on the scale, and again, exclaim:  `` 10 ounces!''

One night, around 2 am, after playing a gig in a medium-sized town several hours away, we decided to stop at an all-night dinner in a small town on our way home.
The group I was with agreed that this would be fine and patiently waited.
My group and I were fairly frustrated by now, but with no other eating options for two hours in either direction we agree that we should just wait it out.
As we reviewed the menus, a tuxedo-clad waiter came to our table and asked if we were ready to order.
The waiter said nothing the rest of the evening about us having to leave early, but he was clearly peeved.

caveman: We remain for hour to spite.
original: Just to spite him, we remained at our table for nearly 3 hours.
I usually tip well, but I gave the waiter 12 %, which actually was too much.
